review.title: A DIKW Paradigm to Cognitive Engineering
review.abstract: Though the word cognitive has a wide range of meanings we define cognitive engineering as learning from brain to bolster engineering solutions. However, giving an achievable framework to the process towards this has been a difficult task. In this work we take the classic data information knowledge wisdom (DIKW) framework to set some achievable goals and sub-goals towards cognitive engineering. A layered framework like DIKW aligns nicely with the layered structure of pre-frontal cortex. And breaking the task into sub-tasks based on the layers also makes it easier to start developmental endeavours towards achieving the final goal of a brain-inspired system.

metadata.title: A DIKW Paradigm to Cognitive Engineering

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: It is possible that we will see this billion-dollar investment in the development of the new discipline of artificial neural networks (ANN). ANNs have undergone several generations of important developments. Cognitive Architecture (CA) in general and BICA in particular also has a long history and efforts to emulate functioning cognitive architectures (BICA). Cognitive Architecture (BICA) in particular has a high priority.

sections.heading: 2 The DIKW Model of Cognition
sections.text: In fact, most of them are able to determine for themselves what they want and what they want to do.

sections.heading: 3 Achieving Cognition through the DIKW Model
sections.text: In this section, we expand the block diagram by transforming it from one block to another. We can leave the top blocks and transform all the layers we reach from the bottom level.

sections.heading: 4 Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we presented the model of the prefrontal cortex based on a DIKW paradigm, the prefrontal cortex is attributed to cognition in the human brain. Therefore, we believe that the implementation of this approach will create a truly cognitive system.The merit of the architecture presented is that it is based on the DIKW paradigm, which is well understood and therefore enables an easy understanding of the architecture.Secondly, this approach has helped us to break down the architecture into different blocks, which helps in the further analysis of the architecture and helps in its implementation. Finally, we have also provided execution blocks that allow a complete implementation of the architecture.It can be noted that almost three of the execution blocks cannot be implemented with the current technology.However, the beauty of the architecture is that due to the layering of nature, we can still implement a part of it and experiment with it. This also helps in defining a roadmap for the future development, which will help in the implementation of the architecture to the fulle.We believe that the proposed architecture will also help cognitive engineers in the implementation of the architecture.

referenceMentions.context: ANNs have been through several generations of major developments, with the recent phase consisting of spiking neural networks based works [1].
Another parallel field of computational neuroscience has been the bio-inspired cognitive architectures (BICA) [2] a field which got major thrust in development.
CAs like SOAR and ACT-R have been under development for many decades and have been applied in various studies [3, 4].

metadata.abstractText: Though the word “cognitive” has a wide range of meanings we define cognitive engineering as learning from brain to bolster engineering solutions. However, giving an achievable framework to the process towards this has been a difficult task. In this work we take the classic data-information-knowledge-wisdom (DIKW) framework to set some achievable goals and sub-goals towards cognitive engineering. A layered framework like DIKW aligns nicely with the layered structure of prefrontal cortex. And breaking the task into sub-tasks based on the layers also makes it easier to start developmental endeavours towards achieving the final goal of a brain-inspired system. machine learning, cognitive architecture, bio-inspired, Big-Data
